pr_title: Update release guide with extended information.

timeline.message: Update release guide with extended information.
Add link to mass comment script

timeline.bodyText: This worked fine for me. What was the issue for you?
timeline.author: udim
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -125,7 +125,7 @@ __NOTE__: When generating the key, please make sure you choose the key type as _
 
 * Determine your Apache GPG Key and Key ID, as follows:
 
-      gpg --list-keys

replies.bodyText: It depends on version of gpg installed i guess. New version requires updated command to produce same output.
replies.author: Ardagan

replies.bodyText:
I'm using the latest release (2.2.19), and --list-keys works fine. I'd rather not complicate the command.
$ gpg --list-keys
/usr/local/google/home/ehudm/.gnupg/pubring.kbx
-----------------------------------------------
pub   rsa4096 2019-12-04 [SC]
      8961F3EF8E796688406787CF587B049C36DAAFE6
uid           [ultimate] Udi Meiri (CODE SIGNING KEY) <udim@>
sub   rsa4096 2019-12-04 [E]
... # other keys

$ gpg --version
gpg (GnuPG) 2.2.19
libgcrypt 1.8.5
replies.author: udim

replies.bodyText: To be clear, I used the shortened fingerprint string 587B049C36DAAFE6 as the key ID, which is not displayed anymore in --list-keys, but I believe the full fingerprint should work too. Up to you if you want to change it.
replies.author: udim

timeline.bodyText: I also had issues with figuring this out, but it is written already in line 588 above. Not sure if it's worth repeating so close by.
timeline.author: udim
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -595,6 +600,9 @@ For this step, we recommend you using automation script to create a RC, but you
   1. Update last release download links in `website/src/get-started/downloads.md`.
   1. Update `website/src/.htaccess` to redirect to the new version.
   1. Build and stage python wheels.
+  1. Public staging artifacts

replies.bodyText: Would it be worth removing from line 588?
replies.author: Ardagan

replies.bodyText: Probably, yes, since we both skimmed over that list above and missed the comment, but I do remember looking at this list for help. I'd move this to be the first item (chronological order).
replies.author: udim

timeline.author: udim

replies.bodyText: Yes. Will make it more detailed.
replies.author: Ardagan

replies.bodyText: Okay - I thought you meant to link to the twine homepage.
replies.author: udim

replies.bodyText: This page describes how packaging works for python, including using twine for publishing binaries. I find it more useful.
replies.author: Ardagan

timeline.bodyText:
For brevity, could this just say: "use pip install twine to install twine locally or in a virtualenv of your choice"?
Otherwise, I'd also write down to deactivate and clean up env/ when done.
timeline.author: udim
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -1248,6 +1256,14 @@ please follow [the guide](https://help.github.com/articles/creating-a-personal-a
    delete the `.asc`, `.sha512`;
 3. Upload the new release `twine upload *` from the directory with the `.zip` and `.whl` files;
 
+[Installing twine](https://packaging.python.org/tutorials/packaging-projects/):
+```
+virtualenv env
+. ./env/bin/activate

timeline.bodyText:
This will install twine globally. This works but it may not be what people want.
suggestion -> install twine in a virtualenv.
timeline.author: aaltay

replies.bodyText:
This is opposite to Udis suggestion to remove the virtualenv part.
Should we assume that people will know the option of running any python command in virtual env?
replies.author: Ardagan

replies.bodyText:
I would not assume that. Not everyone works with regularly and may just run the pip command directly.
@udim what do you think?
replies.author: aaltay
